item.title: Plastic Free July
item.description: A few days into July I caught wind of the ‘Plastic Free July’ movement on Facebook. I’m always eager to partake in anything that contributes to a more sustainable lifestyle, especially if it also serves to educate myself on the larger climate narrative. TL;DR: it was H A R D.

item.title: A collective crisis, but who bears the burden?
item.description: More than once I’ve been asked to justify why I choose to do seemingly inconvenient things like carry my compost to school, eat vegan, and buy non-plastic products that are 3x the price of their plastic counterpart. Often my challengers want me to admit that my actions amount to buying us something like one-one trillionth more time on Earth, and that it’s pointless.

item.title: Takeaways from the Wharton Energy Conference
item.description: Since immersing myself into the conservation world, I’ve tried to take every opportunity to learn more so that I can gain a better understanding of the problems we will face in our lifetimes. So with no idea of what to expect and minimal background knowledge on the energy industry, I attended the Wharton Energy Conference.

item.title: Rob Stewart is my hero.
item.description: Growing up in a land-locked area, I had little exposure to the ocean and the creatures that call it home. So it was a bit unusual that I developed a deep-seated love for the predator of the seas - sharks. The moment I looked past their media-driven reputation as ruthless killers, I discovered their worth.
